journal-title-group.journal-title: Quarterly Journal of Business and Economics

publisher.publisher-name: College of Business Administration of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln

title-group.article-title: Middle Managers in Banking: An Investigation of Gender Differences in Behavior, Demographics, and Productivity

abstract.p: This study investigates gender differences in demographic, job productivity, and behavioral factors for 106 bank middle managers. The results indicate that men and women display significant differences with respect to age, marital status, education, experience, number of positions and promotions, length of time in each position, and restrictions on employment such as lack of job mobility because of spousal employment. Only minimal differences are attributed to behavioral factors related to career advancement. While average job levels and salaries are equal for men and women, gender appears to play a significant role in wage determination when controlling for differences in productivity and behavioral characteristics.
